_exec_summary.SummaryText:
RMP Executive Summary

GSC 777 Freeport Pkwy LLC is leasing the property at 777 Freeport Parkway in Coppell, Texas. Prior to occupation, it was stated by the previous occupant, that the facility had decreased the charge to below 10,000 pounds and deregistered the process. This submittal has been prepared to reflect the addition of approximately 8,035 pounds of ammonia to the existing system. Based on information that was available and provided by the site, this executive summary has been prepared.



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

GSC 777 Freeport Pkwy LLC is committed to the safety of its employees and neighbors and operates the Facility as a responsible member of the community. Personnel are encouraged to continually identify methods and procedures to reduce the use of and risks associated with hazardous chemicals. This process includes protecting the community, environment, and Facility personnel by implementing technology and procedures designed to reduce the impact of any potential release of toxic chemicals. This commitment to safety is documented in the policy and compliance manuals for the Facility, which are available to all employees.



Regulated Substance

GSC 777 Freeport Pkwy LLC utilizes anhydrous ammonia within a refrigeration system at the Facility. The facility uses approximately 16,900 pounds of anhydrous ammonia.



Off-site Release Scenarios

GSC 777 Freeport Pkwy LLC has conducted an OCA based on the EPA document titled "RMP Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidelines," and used the EPA's RMP*Comp Version 1.07 to estimate the distance traveled to a toxic endpoint defined by the EPA regulation. This data were then used to estimate the potential impact caused by a release from each of the regulated substances.



Worst-Case Release Scenarios

As required by regulations, scenarios were considered where the entire capacity of the largest vessel for each regulated chemical at the facility was released in 10 minutes (the m

aximum charge of the facility was used as it is less than the maximum capacity of the largest vessel). Although these scenarios are highly unlikely in the event of a release, it provides the local responding agencies with a maximum possible impact in the event of an accidental release. In considering these releases, the most pessimistic meteorological conditions were used. Passive mitigation measures were taken into account when considering these release scenarios.



Alternative Release Scenarios

Alternative scenarios were developed to assess what potential impact may occur in the event of a release that is more likely to occur than the worst-case scenarios for each of the regulated chemicals. Several possible release scenarios were considered, and the scenarios with the greatest offsite impact were chosen. In considering the alternative release scenario, the default meteorological conditions for alternative scenarios were used in RMP*Comp. These scenarios represent a more realistic release, and have a downwind distance and impact considerably smaller than the worst-case scenario. No passive or active mitigation measures were taken into account when considering these release scenarios.



General Accidental Release Prevention Programs and Prevention Steps

As part of the implementation of the RMP, elements of the prevention programs have been developed to manage process safety issues associated with the facility. Each of the program elements has been developed according to OSHA and EPA regulations in order to ensure safe operating practices and conditions at the GSC 777 Freeport Pkwy LLC facility. 



Elements of Prevention Program 3 include the following:

- Process Safety Information - information regarding the hazards of anhydrous ammonia, process description, and equipment properties

- Process Hazard Analysis - a detailed review of the process, and recommendations to improve the safety of the systems at the Facility

- Operating Procedures - procedures design

ed to comply with regulations and provide safe practices for the systems at the Facility

- Training - procedures and logs for personnel training on the covered process

- Mechanical Integrity - manufacturer recommended maintenance procedures, schedules, and documentation

- Management of Change - documentation and tracking of changes that effect the process involving the regulated chemical

- Pre-Startup Review - prior to the startup of a new regulated process or major changes to the existing process, a review will be conducted, as required by PSM and RMP regulations

- Compliance Audits - documentation of triennial audits of the covered process

- Incident Investigation - documentation and investigation procedures for determining and mitigating releases

- Employee Participation - documentation and statement of commitment to providing a safe and open work place

- Hot Work Permit - procedures for documenting and safely performing work on or near process equipment during normal operations

- Contractors - policy for contractors and outside vendors that work on or near the regulated process 



These elements are continually updated and reviewed through the Management System at the Facility. The Management System includes planning, organizing, implementing, and controlling different aspects of the plan.



Five Year Accident History

There have been no significant releases of ammonia at the Facility in the last five years (March 2016 - March 2011) of ammonia that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity of 100 pounds. In addition, there have been no injuries resulting from an ammonia release.



Process Description

The refrigeration cycle begins with the transfer of liquid ammonia from the Condensers (EC1 and EC2) to the High Pressure Receiver (V-4). The High Pressure Receiver provides priority liquid ammonia to the Compressors for oil cooling. The High Pressure Receiver receives a liquid / vapor mixture from the oil coolers on the compressors. Excess liquid in the

High Pressure Receiver is sent to the High Temperature Recirculator (V-3).

The High Temperature Recirculator receives high pressure liquid from the High Pressure Receiver. It provides liquid makeup to the Medium Temperature Recirculator (V-2) and pumps high temperature liquid to the Banana Room Evaporators (AU-30 thru AU-41, AU-50 thru AU-53), Produce Dock Evaporators (AU-42-47), the Center Dock Area Evaporator (AU-48) and the Dock Area Evaporator (AU-49). These evaporators return high temperature recirculated suction back to the same vessel. Compressor 3 and 4 draw suction from the High Temperature Recirculator.

The Medium Temperature Recirculator (V-2) receives liquid makeup from the High Temperature Recirculator. If provides liquid makeup to the Low Temperature Recirculator (V-1) and pumps medium temperature liquid to the following evaporators: Dairy Room 3 Evaporators (AU-1 thru AU-3), Box Beef Room 2 Evaporators (AU-4 thru AU-6), South Dock Evaporators (AU-12 thru AU-17), GL Foods Room Evaporators (AU-23 thru AU-25), Wet Produce Shrimp Room Evaporator (AU-26), and the Room 7 Evaporators (AU-27 and AU28). The resulting medium temperature recirculated suction form these evaporators is returned to the same vessel. Compressor 2 and 4 draw medium temperature economizer suction form the Medium Temperature Recirculator.

The Low Temperature Recirculator (V-1) receives liquid makeup from the Medium Temperature Recirculator. It pumps low temperature liquid to the Freezer 1 Evaporators (AU-7 thru AU-11) and the Package Meat Room 4 Evaporators (AU-18 thru AU-20). The resulting low temperature recirculated suction from these evaporators is returned to the Low Temperature Recirculator. Vapor is drawn off the vessel by Compressors 1, 4 and 5.

Compressors 1 and 5 draw low temperature suction from the Low Temperature Recirculator. Compressors 1 and 2 draw medium temperature economizer suction from the Medium Temperature Recirculator. Compressor 3 draws high temperature suc

tion from the High Temperature Recirculator. Compressor 4 acts as a swing compressor and can draw suction from any of the Recirculators. All of the compressors are equipped with oil coolers and receive priority liquid form the High Pressure Receiver. All of the compressors discharge compressed ammonia vapor (hot gas) to the Condensers (EC-1 and EC-2). A portion of the hot gas is routed to the Underfloor Heat Exchanger for heating glycol. Hot gas is also sent to the following evaporators for coil defrost: AU-1 thru AU-20, AU-23, and AU-25 thru AU-28.

The Underfloor Heat Exchanger (HX-1) is a shell and tube heat exchanger which is designed to be used in a separate, closed loop system for under floor heating. The Underfloor Heat Exchanger receives hot gas from the Compressors. As the high temperature ammonia vapor passes through the heat exchanger unit, it is partially condensed as the glycol absorbs heat from the ammonia. The resulting liquid/vapor mixture flows to the Medium Temperature Recirculator.

At the Condensers (EC-1 and EC-2) air (fans) and water (pumps) are used to condense the hot gas from the Compressors into high pressure liquid, which drains to the Thermosyphon Pilot Receiver to begin the refrigeration cycle again. The system is also equipped with an Automatic Purger that removes non-condensables, i.e. air, from the system.

The ASME vessels and compressor oil separators are equipped with pressure relief valves which are set to actuate at 250 psig. All of the relief valves (except for the Underfloor Heat Exchanger) are tied into a common relief header that vents to the atmosphere. The Underfloor Heat Exchanger has a separate relief line that vents to the atmosphere



Emergency Response Program

C&S has developed an Ammonia Emergency Action Plan (Refrigeration Emergency Response Plan)

which includes but is not limited to the following:

- emergency response and evacuation procedures

- safety and health considerations

- notification procedures

- loc

al emergency response agencies

- environmental offsite consequences



Planned Changes

Changes determined by the most recent PHA and considerations made during the development of this plan will be conducted in a timely manner.



Updates

The RMP for the Facility will be updated at least every five years, and, with this anniversary reset is next due to be updated in March 2021.
